[[Bill Anderson (singer)|Bill Anderson]] | website = {{URL|michellenixon.com/}} }} '''Michelle Nixon''' is a [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]] and acoustic [[country music]] artist. Born '''Michelle Denice Thurston'''{{cite web |url=http://www.michellenixon.com/biography_michelle.html |title=Michelle Nixon Biography – Michelle Nixon & Drive |publisher=Michellenixon.com |accessdate=2010-07-03 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090107030652/http://www.michellenixon.com/biography_michelle.html |archivedate=January 7, 2009 |df=mdy-all }} on December 10, 1963{{cite web|url=http://www.facebook.com/people/Michelle-Nixon/543021132#!/profile.php?id=100000170173249&ref=sgm |title=Niet compatibele browser |publisher=Facebook |date= |accessdate=2010-07-03}} she grew up in central [[Virginia]] where she became involved in music at an early age. Nixon joined her first band at the age of 14, embarking on a musical journey that found her singing a variety of [[gospel music|gospel]] and classic [[country music]] with different [[Virginia]] based bands.{{cite web |url=http://waynerice.com/bgbios/ |title=Bluegrass Bios |publisher=Waynerice.com |date= |accessdate=2010-07-03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100719132405/http://waynerice.com/bgbios/ |archive-date=July 19, 2010 |url-status=dead }} Gathering inspiration and style from, among others, [[Loretta Lynn]] and [[Emmylou Harris]], Nixon quickly developed her own powerful sound.{{cite web|url=http://www.sptimes.com/2006/04/28/Pasco/After_years_playing_b.shtml |title=Singer Back on Stage |publisher=St Petersburg Times |date=April 28, 2006 |accessdate=2010-07-03}} ==History== Michelle Nixon began her professional music career when she formed the band Slate River with her husband Nick in 1989. In 1990 and 1991, Nixon won the Virginia Folk Music Association's female vocalist award.{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/michelle_nixon_drive/bio.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040725043558/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/michelle_nixon_drive/bio.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=July 25, 2004 |title=Michelle Nixon & Drive : Biography |publisher=CMT.com |date= |accessdate=2010-07-03}} Nixon teamed up with [[mandolin]] player / vocalist Vernon Hughes in the band "Appalachian Express" in 1993. In 1996, they joined to create the Virginia Band "Local Exchange"{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/timesdispatch/access/425187021.html?dids=425187021:425187021&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Oct+16%2C+2003&author=Tom+Netherland&pub=Richmond+Times+-+Dispatch&desc=MAKING+A+NAME+IN+MUSIC+SCENE&pqatl=google |title=Making A Name in the Music Scene |publisher=Richmond Times and Dispatch |date=October 16, 2003 |accessdate=2010-07-03 | first=Tom | last=Netherland}}{{dead link|date=July 2024|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} and released the album "Because He Lives" on Copper Creek Records. After playing a key role in the Virginia Band "Local Exchange", Nixon formed her current band – Michelle Nixon & Drive – in 2002. Within a year, Nixon signed a three-album contract with Pinecastle Records. In the following years Nixon was consecutively nominated for Female Vocalist of the Year (Traditional) at the National SPBGMA (Society for the Preservation of Bluegrass in America) convention in [[Nashville]], [[Tennessee|TN]] from 2004 to 2009.{{cite web |url=http://www.spbgma.com/level2/natnom2004.html |title=2004 Music Award Nominees |publisher=SPBGMA |accessdate=2010-07-03 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101207014017/http://www.spbgma.com/level2/natnom2004.html |archivedate=December 7, 2010 |df=mdy-all }} In 2006 she was the recipient of the Female Vocalist of the Year (Traditional) at the SPBGMA convention.{{cite web |url=http://www.spbgma.com/level2/natawd2006.html |title=SPBGMA 2006 |publisher=SPBGMA |accessdate=2010-07-03 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101207020824/http://www.spbgma.com/level2/natawd2006.html |archivedate=December 7, 2010 |df=mdy-all }} In total "Michelle Nixon and Drive" received a total of six nominations at SPBGMA in 2006.{{cite web|url=http://www.hoperiverentertainment.com/MN_pressrelease_2006_spbgma.htm|title=Michelle Nixon Named 2006 SPBGMA Traditional Female Vocalist of the Year|publisher=Hope River Entertainment|accessdate=2010-07-03|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110712215818/http://www.hoperiverentertainment.com/MN_pressrelease_2006_spbgma.htm|archivedate=July 12, 2011|df=mdy-all}} Additionally from 2005 to 2009 Nixon was nominated for SPBGMA's Entertainer of the Year.{{cite web |url=http://spbgma.com/awards-nominees/index.html |title=Archived Music Award Nominees |publisher=SPBGMA |accessdate=2010-07-03 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100605085906/http://www.spbgma.com/awards-nominees/index.html |archivedate=June 5, 2010 |df=mdy-all }} Nixon participated in the much acclaimed "Daughter's of Bluegrass" series of albums both with singing and her song writing abilities. On the 2006 release "Daughter's of Bluegrass – Back to the Well" Nixon co-wrote the song "Grass Angels" and performed on several of the cuts including a duet with fellow Bluegrass artist Jeanette Williams entitled "How's it Feel" which was written by Dixie and [[Tom T. Hall]].{{cite web|url=http://www.daughtersofbluegrass.com/back%20to%20the%20well.html |title= Back to The Well Album |publisher=Daughtersofbluegrass.com |date= |accessdate=2010-07-03}} Blue Circle Records continued the "Daughter's of Bluegrass Series" with the album "Daughter's of Bluegrass – Bluegrass Bouquet" in late 2008. Michelle Nixon again provided her vocal talents to this various artist project.{{cite web |url=http://www.daughtersofbluegrass.com/bluegrass%20bouquet.html |title = DaughtersOfBluegrass.com}} For both of these projects Nixon was a recipient of the [[International Bluegrass Music Awards|IBMA]] Recording Event of the Year Award in 2006 and 2009 respectively.{{cite web |url=http://cms.ibma.org/site/ibma.awards/recipients/#recorded |title=Past Recipients | IBMA Awards | International Bluegrass Music Association | IBMA.Org |publisher=Cms.ibma.org |date=March 24, 2006 |accessdate=2010-07-03 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111004163846/http://cms.ibma.org/site/ibma.awards/recipients/#recorded |archivedate=October 4, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} In 2007, Nixon toured as part of the "Blowin' the Dust Off" tour with Steve Bassett.*[http://www.thebluegrassblog.com/michelle-nixon-and-steve-bassett-blowin-the-dust-off/ Bluegrassblog.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725104101/http://www.thebluegrassblog.com/michelle-nixon-and-steve-bassett-blowin-the-dust-off/ |date=July 25, 2011 }} Blowin' The Dust Off Tour During this same tour season, she played several Bluegrass Festivals that were not part of the Blowin' The Dust Off Tour including Sertoma Youth Ranch Spring Bluegrass Festival in Florida.*[http://www.sptimes.com/2007/04/30/Hernando/Plenty_of_picking___a.shtml St Petersburg Times] Hernado Festival Also in 2007 Nixon and her band Drive performed in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, as part of the Bluegrass Sundays Winter Concert Series.''Strings'', newsletter of the Pineridge Bluegrass Folklore Society, January 2007 In 2008, Nixon performed at the Induction ceremonies for the newest members of the Country Music Hall of Fame [[Tom T. Hall]] and the [[Statler Brothers]] at the request of veteran songwriter Tom T. Hall. Her performance included his song "Harper Valley PTA" which she had recently recorded for her next album.*[https://web.archive.org/web/20080704131100/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1590207/with-music-and-laughter-tom-t-hall-and-the-statlers-stride-into-the-hall-of-fame.jhtml CMT] Article on Country Music Hall of Fame Induction ==Songwriting== Nixon has focused more and more on her songwriting. She wrote two to three songs on each of her Pinecastle albums. She also contributed as a songwriter to the [[International Bluegrass Music Awards|IBMA]]-winning Daughter's of Bluegrass Album ''Back to The Well'' and co-wrote the song "When It's Christmas in Virginia" with her husband Nick Nixon for the ''A Pinecastle Christmas Gathering'' album. In more recent years Nixon's songs have been performed and recorded by other Bluegrass artist such as Dianne McKoy.{{cite web |url=http://cybergrass.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=3197 |title=African-American Woman Cranks Up 27-Year Niche |publisher=Cybergrass.com |date=April 22, 2007 |accessdate=2010-07-03 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110116203431/http://cybergrass.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=3197 |archivedate=January 16, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} ==Style== Nixon's overall style would be called Contemporary Bluegrass or Acoustic Country. She has a wide range of vocal and instrumental abilities and often performs both smooth [[ballad]]s and hard driving Bluegrass. She is well known for performing classic country anthems and remaking them in her own style. In her performances and recording projects, she has shown her ability to shine as a solo vocalist as well as an outstanding ability to sing harmony that she learned as a girl singing gospel music. She performed and/or recorded projects with many [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]] artist such as Jeanette Williams and [[Dale Ann Bradley]] as well as [[Country music]] performer and [[Grand Ole Opry]] star [[Bill Anderson (singer)|Bill Anderson]].{{cite web|author=CYBERGRASS The Internet Bluegrass Music News Magazine |url=http://www.cybergrass.com//modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=1170 |title=Cybergrass Bluegrass Music News: Michelle Nixon & Drive Making Their Marks on the Charts |location=US |publisher=Cybergrass.com |date= |accessdate=2010-07-03}} ==Personal life== Nixon is married to Nick Nixon and she has three children – Tia, Chip and Trace. She balances a busy musical career and family life while still finding time for the great outdoors. She loves to spend her "spare" time gardening, fishing and [[camping]]. Her husband Nick is an acoustic country artist who collaborates with Nixon. He has most recently been listed as a band member in "Drive".{{cite web|url=http://www.facebook.com/pages/Michelle-Nixon-Drive/107465332636121 |title=Niet compatibele browser |publisher=Facebook |date= |accessdate=2010-07-03}} In 2005 Nixon postponed her California tour due to an illness in the family. Her daughter was undergoing her fourth heart surgery.{{cite web |url=http://www.cybergrass.com/modules.php?name=News&file=print&sid=658 |title=Michelle Nixon Postpones California Tour |publisher=Cybergrass.com |date=November 17, 2004 |accessdate=2010-07-03 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708215644/http://www.cybergrass.com/modules.php?name=News&file=print&sid=658 |archivedate=July 8, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} Due to her own personal experiences, Nixon has often worked with charity organizations such as the [[American Heart Association]] and the [[Shriners]]. For the past several years she has been the host for the Bluegrass in the Blue Ridge [[Bluegrass music|Bluegrass]] Festival in [[Luray, Virginia|Luray]], [[Virginia|VA]] which is a fund raiser for the [[Shriners]] Hospitals for Children.{{cite web|url=http://www.bluegrassinluray.com/ |title= Bluegrass in The Blue Ridge |publisher=bluegrassinluray.com |date= |accessdate=2010-07-03}} ==Discography== *Local Exchange – Because He Lives – [[Copper Creek Records]] 2001 *Michelle Nixon and Drive – It's My Turn – [[Pinecastle Records|Pinecastle]] 2003 *Michelle Nixon and Drive – By Request – Pinecastle 2004 *Various Artists – A Pinecastle Christmas Gatherin' – Pinecastle 2004 *Michelle Nixon and Drive – What More Should I Say – Pinecastle 2005 *Daughter's of Bluegrass (Various Artists) – Back to the Well – Blue Circle Records 2006 *Daughter's of Bluegrass (Various Artists) – Bluegrass Bouquet – Blue Circle Records 2008 *Michelle Nixon and Drive – A Place I Belong – Mountain Fever Records 2011 ==See also== *[[Bluegrass music]] *[[International Bluegrass Music Association]] *[[Bill Anderson (singer)]] *[[Tom T.
